title: Understanding Reliability
text: Reliability in research refers to the consistency of a measure. A study is considered reliable if it produces similar results under consistent conditions.

hintAnswer: To ensure consistent results across different trials and conditions
title: Importance of Reliability
text: Why is it important for research studies to demonstrate reliability?
choices: To ensure consistent results across different trials and conditions
To increase the number of participants in the study
To allow researchers to use more complex statistical methods
To make the study more appealing to funding agencies

title: Types of Reliability
text: There are several types of reliability, including test-retest reliability, inter-rater reliability, and internal consistency. Each type assesses different aspects of consistency in research.

hintAnswer: The stability of a test over time
title: Test-Retest Reliability
text: What does test-retest reliability measure in a research study?
choices: The stability of a test over time
The consistency of items within a test
The validity of the test results

title: Inter-Rater Reliability
text: Inter-rater reliability measures the degree of agreement among different observers or raters.

hintAnswer: The consistency of items within a test
title: Internal Consistency
text: What does internal consistency measure in a research study?
choices: The consistency of items within a test
The stability of a test over time
The validity of the test results
